Acne.description: Acne is a skin condition that occurs when your hair follicles become plugged with oil and dead skin cells.
Acne.causes: Excess oil production, hair follicles clogged by oil and dead skin cells, bacteria, and inflammation.
Acne.care: Wash your face twice a day, use non-comedogenic products, and avoid picking at pimples.
Acne.recommendations: Consider using over-the-counter treatments with benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid. See a dermatologist for severe cases.

Atopic_Dermatitis.description: Also known as eczema, atopic dermatitis makes your skin red and itchy.
Atopic_Dermatitis.causes: A combination of genetic, environmental, and immune system factors.
Atopic_Dermatitis.care: Moisturize your skin at least twice a day, avoid harsh soaps, and take shorter, lukewarm baths or showers.
Atopic_Dermatitis.recommendations: Identify and avoid triggers that worsen the inflammation (like certain soaps, detergents, or stress).

Psoriasis.description: Psoriasis is a skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk and scalp.
Psoriasis.causes: An immune system problem that causes skin cells to grow faster than usual.
Psoriasis.care: Keep skin moisturized, use gentle soaps, and try to manage stress.
Psoriasis.recommendations: Exposing your skin to small amounts of sunlight can sometimes help, but be careful of sunburns.

Rosacea.description: Rosacea is a common skin condition that causes flushing or long-term redness on your face.
Rosacea.causes: The exact cause is unknown, but it might be due to a combination of hereditary and environmental factors.
Rosacea.care: Identify and avoid triggers (like spicy foods, hot drinks, or extreme temperatures). Wear sunscreen daily.
Rosacea.recommendations: Use gentle cleansers and avoid products that contain alcohol or other skin irritants.

SkinCancer.description: The abnormal growth of skin cells, most often develops on skin exposed to the sun.
SkinCancer.causes: Damage to DNA in skin cells, often caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight or tanning beds.
SkinCancer.care: Protect your skin from the sun with clothing and sunscreen. Perform regular skin self-exams.
SkinCancer.recommendations: See a dermatologist immediately if you notice any new or changing spots on your skin.

Tinea_Fungal.description: A group of fungal infections of the skin.
Tinea_Fungal.causes: Various types of fungi that thrive in warm, moist areas.
Tinea_Fungal.care: Keep the affected area clean and dry. Avoid sharing personal items like towels or clothing.
Tinea_Fungal.recommendations: Use over-the-counter antifungal creams or powders as directed.

Urticaria_Hives.description: Red, itchy welts that result from a skin reaction.
Urticaria_Hives.causes: Allergies to food, medicine, or other irritants; stress; or infections.
Urticaria_Hives.care: Apply cold compresses to the affected area and wear loose-clothing.
Urticaria_Hives.recommendations: Antihistamines can help relieve the itching and swelling.

Vitiligo.description: A disease that causes loss of skin color in patches.
Vitiligo.causes: The pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) die or stop functioning.
Vitiligo.care: Protect depigmented skin from the sun with clothing or a high-SPF sunscreen.
Vitiligo.recommendations: Cosmetics or sun-tanning products may help reduce the appearance of patches.

Warts.description: Small, grainy skin growths caused by a virus.
Warts.care: Avoid direct contact with warts. Don't pick at them, as they can spread.
Warts.recommendations: Over-the-counter treatments with salicylic acid can often clear warts over time.

Burns Detected.description: Damage to the skin or other organic tissue caused by heat or other radiation, electricity, friction, or contact with chemicals.
Burns Detected.causes: Heat (thermal burns), electricity, chemicals, or radiation (like sunburn).
Burns Detected.care: Cool the burn with lukewarm water. Do not apply ice directly. Cover with a sterile bandage.
Burns Detected.recommendations: Seek medical attention for deep burns, large areas, or burns on the face, hands, or joints.

Jaundice.description: A condition in which the skin, whites of the eyes and mucous membranes turn yellow.
Jaundice.causes: High levels of bilirubin, a yellow-orange bile pigment, in the blood.
Jaundice.care: Treatment focuses on the underlying cause. Stay hydrated.
Jaundice.recommendations: Consult a doctor immediately for diagnosis, as it can indicate liver or gallbladder issues.

Onychomycosis.description: A fungal infection of the fingernails or toenails.
Onychomycosis.causes: Various fungal organisms, most common being dermatophyte.
Onychomycosis.care: Keep nails trimmed and clean. Avoid sharing footwear.
Onychomycosis.recommendations: Antifungal medications (topical or oral) are typically required for treatment.

Nail Psoriasis.description: Psoriasis that affects the fingernails and toenails.
Nail Psoriasis.causes: Same as skin psoriasis (immune system issue).
Nail Psoriasis.care: Keep nails short. Wear gloves when working with your hands.
Nail Psoriasis.recommendations: Consult a dermatologist for specialized treatments like creams or injections.

Pitting.description: Small depressions or dents on the surface of the nail.
Pitting.causes: Often associated with skin conditions like psoriasis or eczema.
Pitting.care: Treatment is usually directed at the underlying condition.
Pitting.recommendations: Regular moisturizing of the nail bed may help.
